subject: Re: [junit] Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with JUnit in a big project, please?
msgSnippet: ... I notice that Joakim wrote guide and Cedric read drive . As far as I know, those words have nonoverlapping meanings. -- J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger ::
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
>
> On 10/27/06, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...
> <mailto:joakim.ohlrogge%40gmail.com>> wrote:
> >
> >
> > I think, when doing TDD the main benefit is not to find bugs it is to
> > guide
> > your design.
>
> Really?
>
> The main reason why I write tests is to make sure that no regressions will
> happen. From the point where I submit my tests, I know that no matter what
> code gets checked in after me, the functionality of the system will not
> decrease.
>
> Tests also help a great deal make my code more robust.
>
> But drive my design with tests? That's dangerous and can potentially lead to
> micro-design, i.e. design without seeing the big picture ("I'll use this
> signature because the test looks cleaner then").

I notice that Joakim wrote "guide" and Cedric read "drive". As far as I
know, those words have nonoverlapping meanings.
